            "name": "Fact Check: Can vitamin D cure cancer? – THIP Media",

Quick Take A social media post claims vitamin D cures cancer and...",
            "text": "Can vitamin D kill cancer cells? No evidence confirms eating only vitamin D cures cancer. Available scientific evidence suggests that vitamins only aid cancer treatment, support healthy recovery, and might prevent cancer relapse. Quick Take A social media post claims vitamin D cures cancer and is the most effective medicine against cancer. We fact-checked and found the claim to be Mostly False. The Claim A Twitter post claims vitamin D is the single most effective medicine against cancer. The post is embedded below: Vitamin D is the single most effective medicine against cancer, far outpacing the benefits of any cancer drug known to modern science. — healthbot (@thehealthb0t) October 6, 2022 Fact Check What is the claimed Twitter post about? The claimed Twitter post seems to spread misinformation as scientific evidence still does not confirm whether vitamin D cures cancer completely. We searched and found that the tweet has been shared by a bot that automatically retweets health-related posts shared on Twitter by other accounts. The claimed Twitter post has received 436 retweets, 14 quote tweets, and 1,935 likes till we last checked. Can vitamin D cure cancer? No. The available research does not confirm vitamin D cures all cancer. The available research only speculates whether vitamin D can kill cancer cells without harming healthy cells and prevent the formation of new ones. The National Cancer Institute (NCI) website informs that exposure to sunlight produces vitamin D. So, researchers hypothesize that a change in vitamin D level might allow cancer-causing components to affect normal cell functioning and cause cancer. Also, this website shows that available evidence is insufficient to confirm that high vitamin D intake lowers cancer incidence. Dr Sarthak Moharir, (MBBS, MD, Radiation Oncology), Consultant Radiation Oncologist at HCG Cancer Centre in Vadodara, Gujarat, informs, “Vitamin D doesn’t cure any cancer. No study proves the same. Vitamin D deficiency is notoriously common in India despite being a sunny country. So, vitamin D supplements are frequently prescribed to patients because cancer treatment leads to decreased food intake and hence decreased vitamin consumption.” Dr Manish Singhal, Senior Oncologist, Apollo Hospital, Delhi, in an interview with THIP MEDIA explained that vitamin D has a preventive role and can avoid cancer relapse. Is vitamin D treatment for breast cancer approved in India? It does not seem so. Indian doctors do not recommend Vitamin D as a chemotherapy drug.  Dr Moharir further informs, “Vitamin D supplements are pointedly given to breast cancer patients because breast cancer treatment frequently involves female hormone blockers. Female hormones are essential for bone health so they need supplements of vitamin D. Vitamin D does not cure any cancer nor is listed as a treatment of choice in any national or international guideline’. Even though evidence suggests vitamin D may play a role in controlling breast cancer cells from growing, the research still does not confirm the correct drug delivery method and optimum dosage to make the use of vitamin D against cancer a standard practice. We also searched and found evidence that shows the daily recommended dose of vitamin d for adults is 4000 IU/day. A high vitamin D dose can cause hypercalcemia or hypercalciuria which causes excess calcium in the body or urine. Disclaimer: Medical Science is an ever evolving field. We strive to keep this page updated. In case you notice any discrepancy in the content, please inform us at factcheck@thip.in. You can futher read our Correction Policy here. Never disregard professional medical advice or delay seeking medical treatment because of something you have read on or accessed through this website or it's social media channels. Read our Full Disclaimer Here for further information.",

<img src="https://static.thip.media/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/16182400/vitamin-d-2.jpg" width="0" height="0" class="skip-lazy" style="width:0;height:0;" alt="" data-pin-description="Can vitamin D kill cancer cells? No evidence confirms eating only vitamin D cures cancer. Available scientific evidence suggests that vitamins only aid cancer treatment, support healthy recovery, and might prevent cancer relapse. Quick Take A social media post claims vitamin D cures cancer and..." />

<div class='alter1'>Can vitamin D kill cancer cells?</div> <div class='alter2'></div> <div class='shortans'>No evidence confirms eating only vitamin D cures cancer. Available scientific evidence suggests that vitamins only aid cancer treatment, support healthy recovery, and might prevent cancer relapse.</div>
<h3 id="h-quick-take"><strong>Quick Take</strong></h3>
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:auto 40%"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img width="359" height="332" src="https://static.thip.media/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/16184302/mostly-false.png" alt="Rating" class="wp-image-4722 size-full" srcset="https://static.thip.media/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/16184302/mostly-false.png 359w, https://static.thip.media/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/16184302/mostly-false-300x277.png 300w" sizes="(max-width: 359px) 100vw, 359px" /></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content">
<p class="has-regular-font-size">A social media post claims vitamin D cures cancer and is the most effective medicine against cancer. We fact-checked and found the claim to be <strong>Mostly False</strong>. </p>
</div></div>
<h3><strong>The Claim</strong></h3>
<p>A <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://archive.ph/aeZdc">Twitter post</a></span><a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://twitter.com/thehealthb0t/status/1578078928299823104"> </a>claims vitamin D is the single most effective medicine against cancer. The post is embedded below:</p>
<figure class="wp-block-embed is-type-rich is-provider-twitter wp-block-embed-twitter"><div class="wp-block-embed__wrapper">
<blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-width="550" data-dnt="true"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">Vitamin D is the single most effective medicine against cancer, far outpacing the benefits of any cancer drug known to modern science.</p>— healthbot (@thehealthb0t) <a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://twitter.com/thehealthb0t/status/1578078928299823104?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">October 6, 2022</a></blockquote><script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>
</div></figure>
<h3><strong>Fact Check</strong></h3>
<h2><strong>What is the claimed Twitter post about?</strong></h2>
<p>The claimed Twitter post seems to spread misinformation as scientific evidence still does not confirm whether vitamin D cures cancer completely. We searched and found that the tweet has been shared by a bot that automatically retweets health-related posts shared on Twitter by other accounts. The claimed Twitter post has received 436 retweets, 14 quote tweets, and 1,935 likes till we last checked.</p>
<h2><strong>Can vitamin D cure cancer?</strong></h2>
<p>No. The available research does not confirm vitamin D cures all cancer. The available research only speculates whether vitamin D can kill cancer cells without harming healthy cells and prevent the formation of new ones.</p>
<p>The <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/causes-prevention/risk/diet/vitamin-d-fact-sheet">National Cancer Institute (NCI) website</a></span> informs that exposure to sunlight produces vitamin D. So, researchers hypothesize that a change in vitamin D level might allow cancer-causing components to affect normal cell functioning and cause cancer. Also, this website shows that available evidence is insufficient to confirm that high vitamin D intake lowers cancer incidence.</p>
<div class="wp-block-image"><figure class="alignleft size-full"><img width="200" height="203" src="https://static.thip.media/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/07123259/Dr-Sarthak-Moharir.jpg" alt="Sarthak Moharir, Radiation Oncologist" class="wp-image-32018" srcset="https://static.thip.media/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/07123259/Dr-Sarthak-Moharir.jpg 200w, https://static.thip.media/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/07123259/Dr-Sarthak-Moharir-150x152.jpg 150w" sizes="(max-width: 200px) 100vw, 200px" /></figure></div>
<p><strong>Dr Sarthak Moharir</strong>, <strong>(MBBS, MD, Radiation Oncology), Consultant Radiation Oncologist at HCG Cancer Centre in Vadodara, Gujarat</strong>, informs, “Vitamin D doesn’t cure any cancer. No study proves the same. Vitamin D deficiency is notoriously common in India despite being a sunny country. So, vitamin D supplements are frequently prescribed to patients because cancer treatment leads to decreased food intake and hence decreased vitamin consumption.”</p>
<p><strong>Dr Manish Singha</strong>l, <strong>Senior Oncologist, Apollo Hospital, Delhi</strong>, in an interview with THIP MEDIA explained that vitamin D has a preventive role and can avoid cancer relapse. </p>
<figure class="wp-block-embed is-type-video is-provider-youtube wp-block-embed-youtube wp-embed-aspect-16-9 wp-has-aspect-ratio"><div class="wp-block-embed__wrapper">
<iframe title="Trying to get Vitamin D through Sunlight?" width="696" height="392" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/lVtFhR7MA6Y?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>
</div></figure>
<h2><strong>Is vitamin D treatment for breast cancer approved in India?</strong></h2>
<p>It does not seem so. Indian doctors do not recommend Vitamin D as a chemotherapy drug. </p>
<p><strong>Dr Moharir </strong>further informs, “Vitamin D supplements are pointedly given to breast cancer patients because breast cancer treatment frequently involves female hormone blockers. Female hormones are essential for bone health so they need supplements of vitamin D. Vitamin D does not cure any cancer nor is listed as a treatment of choice in any national or international guideline’. Even though <a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18412986/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">evidence</span></a><a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16024246/"> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">suggests</span></a><a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11815408/"> </a><a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11815408/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">vitamin D</span></a><a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17721433/"> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">may play</span></a><a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamanetworkopen/fullarticle/2773074#:~:text=Vitamin%20D%20may%20decrease%20tumor,leading%20to%20reduced%20cancer%20mortality.&text=Higher%20serum%2025%2Dhydroxyvitamin%20D,longer%20survival%20in%20cancer%20patients."><span style="text-decoration: underline;"> a role</span></a> in controlling breast cancer cells from growing, the research still does not confirm the correct drug delivery method and optimum dosage to make the use of vitamin D against cancer a standard practice. We also <a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4463009/"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">searched and</span></a><a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamins-and-minerals/vitamin-d/"> <span style="text-decoration: underline;">found</span> </a><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a rel="noopener nofollow noreferrer" href="https://academic.oup.com/jcem/article/105/4/1261/5634116?login=false">evidence</a></span> that shows the daily recommended dose of vitamin d for adults is 4000 IU/day. A high vitamin D dose can cause hypercalcemia or hypercalciuria which causes excess calcium in the body or urine.</p>
